# Engagement

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Engaged, Betrothed, Affiance, Fiancé, and Fiancée redirect here. For other
uses, see [Engaged (disambiguation)](/wiki/Engaged_\(disambiguation\) "Engaged
\(disambiguation\)"), [Betrothed
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Betrothed_\(disambiguation\) "Betrothed
\(disambiguation\)"), [Affiance (band)](/wiki/Affiance_\(band\) "Affiance
\(band\)"), and [Fiancé (disambiguation)](/wiki/Fianc%C3%A9_\(disambiguation\)
"Fiancé \(disambiguation\)")

For other uses, see [Engagement
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Engagement_\(disambiguation\) "Engagement
\(disambiguation\)").

An **engagement** , **betrothal** , or **fiancer** is a promise to wed, and
also the period of time between a [marriage proposal](/wiki/Marriage_proposal
"Marriage proposal") and a [marriage](/wiki/Marriage "Marriage"). During this
period, a couple is said to be _betrothed,_ _intended_ , _affianced_ ,
_engaged to be married,_ or simply _engaged_. Future [brides](/wiki/Bride
"Bride") and [grooms](/wiki/Groom "Groom") may be called _the betrothed_ , a
_wife-to-be_ or _husband-to-be_ , _fiancée_ or _fiancé_ (from [the French word
of the same form](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/fianc%C3%A9#French
"wikt:fiancé")), respectively. The duration of the courtship varies vastly,
and is largely dependent on cultural norms or upon the agreement of the
parties involved.

Long engagements were once common in formal [arranged
marriages](/wiki/Arranged_marriage "Arranged marriage"), and it was not
uncommon for parents betrothing children to arrange marriages many years
before the engaged couple were old enough. This is still common in some
countries.

## Origin[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Engagement&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Origin")]

The origins of [European](/wiki/Europe "Europe") engagement in marriage
practice is found in the Jewish law ([Torah](/wiki/Torah "Torah")), first
exemplified by [Abraham](/wiki/Abraham "Abraham"), and outlined in the last
[Talmudic](/wiki/Talmud "Talmud") tractate of the [Nashim](/wiki/Nashim
"Nashim") (Women) order, where [marriage](/wiki/Marriage "Marriage") consists
of two separate acts, called _[erusin](/wiki/Erusin_\(Jewish_betrothal\)
"Erusin \(Jewish betrothal\)")_ (or _kiddushin_ , meaning _sanctification_),
which is the [betrothal](/wiki/Betrothal "Betrothal") ceremony, and _nissu
'in_ or _[chupah](/wiki/Chupah "Chupah")_ ,[a] the actual [ceremony for the
marriage](/wiki/Wedding "Wedding"). _Erusin_ changes the couple's
interpersonal status, while _nissu 'in_ brings about the legal consequences of
the change of status. (However, in the Talmud and other sources of Jewish law
there is also a process, called _[kiddushin](/wiki/Kiddush "Kiddush")_ ,
corresponding to what today is called engagement. Marrying without such an
agreement is considered immoral.[1] To complicate matters, _erusin_ in modern
Hebrew means engagement, not betrothal.)

This was later adopted in Ancient Greece as the _gamos_ and _engeysis_
rituals, although unlike in Judaism the contract made in front of witness was
only verbal.[2] The giving of a ring was eventually borrowed from Judaism by
Roman marriage law, with the fiancé presenting it after swearing the oath of
marriage intent, and presenting of the gifts at the engagement party.[3]

## Betrothal[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Engagement&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Betrothal")]

"Betrothed" redirects here. For other uses, see [Betrothed
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Betrothed_\(disambiguation\) "Betrothed
\(disambiguation\)").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Engagement_gifts_basket_%2801%29.jpg/220px-
Engagement_gifts_basket_%2801%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Engagement_gifts_basket_\(01\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Engagement_gifts_basket_\(01\).jpg "Enlarge")

Modern engagement gifts basket in Bangladesh.

**Betrothal** (also called **espousal**) is a formal state of engagement to be
[married](/wiki/Marriage "Marriage").

In [Jewish weddings](/wiki/Jewish_wedding "Jewish wedding") during Talmudic
times (c.1st century BC – 6th century AD), the two ceremonies of betrothal
(_[erusin](/wiki/Erusin_\(Jewish_betrothal\) "Erusin \(Jewish betrothal\)")_)
and wedding usually took place up to a year apart; the bride lived with her
parents until the actual marriage ceremony (_[nissuin](/wiki/Nissuin
"Nissuin")_), which would take place in a room or tent that the groom had set
up for her. Since the Middle Ages the two ceremonies have taken place as a
combined ceremony performed in public. The _betrothal_ is now generally part
of the [Jewish wedding](/wiki/Jewish_wedding "Jewish wedding") ceremony,
accomplished when the groom gives the bride the ring or another object of at
least nominal value.[4] As mentioned above, betrothal in Judaism is separate
from engagement; breaking a betrothal requires a formal
[divorce](/wiki/Get_\(divorce_document\) "Get \(divorce document\)"), and
violation of betrothal is considered [adultery](/wiki/Adultery "Adultery").

Typical steps of a match were the following:

  * Negotiation of a match, usually done by the couple's families with bride and groom having varying levels of input, from no input, to veto power, to a fuller voice in the selection of marriage partner. 
    * This is not as widely practiced as it was historically, although it is still common in culturally conservative communities in [Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel"), [India](/wiki/India "India"), Africa, and Persian Gulf countries, although most of these have a requirement that the bride be at least allowed veto power.
  * Negotiation of [bride price](/wiki/Bride_price "Bride price") or [dowry](/wiki/Dowry "Dowry")
    * In most cultures evolved from Europe, bride prices or dowries have been reduced to the [engagement ring](/wiki/Engagement_ring "Engagement ring") accompanying the marriage contract, while in other cultures, such as those on the Arabian Peninsula, they are still part of negotiating a marriage contract.
  * Blessing by the parents and [clergy](/wiki/Clergy "Clergy")
  * Exchange of Vows and Signing of Contracts 
    * Often one of these is omitted
  * Celebration

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Lionel_Logue_1906.jpg/220px-
Lionel_Logue_1906.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lionel_Logue_1906.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lionel_Logue_1906.jpg "Enlarge")

Engagement photograph of [Lionel Logue](/wiki/Lionel_Logue "Lionel Logue") and
Myrtle Gruenert, 1906.

The exact duration of a betrothal varies according to culture and the
participants’ needs and wishes. For adults, it may be anywhere from several
hours (when the betrothal is incorporated into the wedding day itself) to a
period of several years. A year and a day are common in [neo-pagan](/wiki/Neo-
pagan "Neo-pagan") groups today. In the case of [child
marriage](/wiki/Child_marriage "Child marriage"), betrothal might last from
infancy until the age of marriage.

The responsibilities and privileges of betrothal vary. In most cultures, the
betrothed couple is expected to spend much time together, learning about each
other. In some historical cultures (including [colonial North
America](/wiki/Colonial_North_America "Colonial North America")), the
betrothal was essentially a trial marriage, with marriage only being required
in cases of conception of a child. Almost all cultures are loosening
restrictions against physical contact between partners, even in cultures that
normally had strong prohibitions against it. The betrothal period was also
considered to be a preparatory time, in which the groom built a house, started
a business or otherwise proved his readiness to enter adult society.

In [medieval Europe](/wiki/Medieval_Europe "Medieval Europe"), in [canon
law](/wiki/Canon_law "Canon law"), a betrothal could be formed by the exchange
of [vows](/wiki/Vow "Vow") in the future tense ("I _will_ take you as my
wife/husband," instead of "I take you as my wife/husband"), but sexual
intercourse consummated the vows, making a binding marriage rather than a
betrothal. Although these betrothals could be concluded with only the vows
spoken by the couple, they had legal implications: [Richard III of
England](/wiki/Richard_III_of_England "Richard III of England") had his [older
brother's children](/wiki/Princes_in_the_Tower "Princes in the Tower")
declared illegitimate on the grounds their father had been betrothed to
another woman when he married their mother.

A betrothal is considered to be a 'semi-binding' contract. Normal reasons for
invalidation of a betrothal include:

  * Revelation of a prior commitment or marriage
  * Evidence of [infidelity](/wiki/Infidelity "Infidelity")
  * Failure to conceive (in 'trial marriage' cultures)
  * Failure of either party to meet the financial and property stipulations of the betrothal contract

Normally, either party can break a betrothal, though some financial penalty
(such as forfeit of the bride price) usually applies. In some [common
law](/wiki/Common_law "Common law") countries, including England and Wales and
many US states, it was once possible for the spurned partner (often only the
woman) to sue the other for [breach of promise](/wiki/Breach_of_promise
"Breach of promise") or "heart-balm". This provided some protection in an age
where virginity at marriage was considered important and having a failed
engagement could damage one's reputation, but this [tort](/wiki/Tort "Tort")
has become obsolete in most jurisdictions as attitudes to premarital sex have
softened and emphasis shifted to allowing people to leave loveless
relationships.[5]

### Protestant
Churches[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Engagement&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Protestant Churches")]

The Rite of Betrothal in the [Anglican Communion](/wiki/Anglican_Communion
"Anglican Communion") is found within [The Book of Common
Prayer](/wiki/The_Book_of_Common_Prayer "The Book of Common Prayer"), first
published in 1549.[6] The Anglican Communion, as well as the Methodist Church
and Presbyterian Church, has questions & responses for family members in its
Rite of Betrothal.[7]

### Orthodox
Churches[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Engagement&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Orthodox Churches")]

In the [Eastern Orthodox](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox "Eastern Orthodox") and
[Oriental Orthodox](/wiki/Oriental_Orthodox "Oriental Orthodox") Churches, the
Rite of Betrothal is traditionally performed in the [narthex](/wiki/Narthex
"Narthex") (entranceway) of the church, to indicate the couple's first
entrance into the married estate. The priest blesses the couple and gives them
lit candles to hold. Then, after a [litany](/wiki/Ektenia "Ektenia"), and a
prayer at which everyone bows, he places the bride's ring on the ring finger
of the groom's right hand, and the groom's ring on the bride's finger. The
rings are subsequently exchanged three times, either by the priest or by the
best man, after which the priest says a final prayer. Originally, the
betrothal service would take place at the time the engagement was announced.
In recent times, however, it tends to be performed immediately before the
wedding ceremony itself. The exchange of rings is not a part of the wedding
service in the Eastern Churches, but only occurs at the betrothal.
Traditionally, the groom's ring is gold and the bride's ring is silver.[8]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Les_Tr%C3%A8s_Riches_Heures_du_duc_de_Berry_avril.jpg/170px-
Les_Tr%C3%A8s_Riches_Heures_du_duc_de_Berry_avril.jpg)](/wiki/File:Les_Tr%C3%A8s_Riches_Heures_du_duc_de_Berry_avril.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Les_Tr%C3%A8s_Riches_Heures_du_duc_de_Berry_avril.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Très Riches Heures du Duc de
Berry](/wiki/Tr%C3%A8s_Riches_Heures_du_Duc_de_Berry "Très Riches Heures du
Duc de Berry") depicting a betrothal. [Musée
Condé](/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_Cond%C3%A9 "Musée Condé"),
[Chantilly](/wiki/Chantilly,_Oise "Chantilly, Oise").

### Roman Catholic
Church[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Engagement&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Roman Catholic Church")]

Historically, betrothal in Roman Catholicism was a formal
[contract](/wiki/Contract "Contract") considered as binding as marriage, and a
divorce was necessary to terminate a betrothal.[9] Betrothed couples were
regarded legally as husband and wife – even before their wedding and physical
union. The concept of an official engagement period in [Western
European](/wiki/Western_European "Western European") culture may have begun in
1215 at the [Fourth Lateran Council](/wiki/Fourth_Lateran_Council "Fourth
Lateran Council"), headed by [Pope Innocent III](/wiki/Pope_Innocent_III "Pope
Innocent III"), which decreed that "marriages are to be ... announced publicly
in the churches by the priests during a suitable and fixed time so that, if
legitimate [impediments](/wiki/Canonical_impediment "Canonical impediment")
exist, they may be made known."[10][11] Such a formal church announcement of
the intent to marry is known as [banns](/wiki/Banns "Banns"). In some
jurisdictions, reading the banns may be part of one type of legal marriage.

## Engagement rings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Engagement&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Engagement rings")]

Main article: [Engagement ring](/wiki/Engagement_ring "Engagement ring")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Wedding_and_Engagement_Rings_2151px.jpg/220px-
Wedding_and_Engagement_Rings_2151px.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wedding_and_Engagement_Rings_2151px.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Wedding_and_Engagement_Rings_2151px.jpg "Enlarge")

A [white gold](/wiki/White_gold "White gold") [wedding
ring](/wiki/Wedding_ring "Wedding ring") and a single-[diamond](/wiki/Diamond
"Diamond"), [gold](/wiki/Gold "Gold")-banded engagement ring. The engagement
ring is usually worn on the outside.

Customs for engagement rings vary according to time, place, and culture. An
engagement ring has historically been uncommon, and when such a gift was
given, it was separate from the wedding ring.

The first recorded tradition of giving a ring for marriage is in [Genesis
24:22](http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0124.htm#22) of the [Hebrew
Bible](/wiki/Hebrew_Bible "Hebrew Bible") when a golden nose ring ([Chayei
Sarah](/wiki/Chayei_Sarah_\(parsha\) "Chayei Sarah \(parsha\)") 24:22) was
given by [Eliezer of Damascus](/wiki/Eliezer_of_Damascus "Eliezer of
Damascus") to [Rebecca](/wiki/Rebecca
"Rebecca"),[_[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_][12] with [Saadiah
Gaon](/wiki/Saadiah_Gaon "Saadiah Gaon") also citing as a possible source of
the practice in the phrase in [Nehemiah 7:46](http://www.mechon-
mamre.org/p/pt/pt35b07.htm#46) _be’nei tabbaot_ (children of the
rings).[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] The latter case refers to betrothal (see above) rather than
engagement; one of the three ways in which betrothal may be effected in
[Judaism](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism") is by the husband giving the bride money or
an object of at least nominal value. In fact, it is a long-standing practice
within Judaism to contract the betrothal with a ring.

Romantic rings from the time of the [Roman Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman
Empire") sometimes bore clasped hands symbolizing contract,[13] from which the
later [Celtic](/wiki/Celt "Celt") [Claddagh](/wiki/Claddagh_ring "Claddagh
ring") symbol (two hands clasping a heart) may have evolved as a symbol of
love and commitment between two people. Romans believed the circle was a bond
between the two people who were to be married and signified eternity, but was
first practiced on the [fourth finger/ring finger](/wiki/Ring_finger "Ring
finger") by the [Romans](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire"), who believed this
finger to be the beginning of the _[vena amoris](/wiki/Vena_amoris "Vena
amoris")_ ("vein of love"), the vein that leads to the heart.[14] In cultures
with European origin, and many other countries, an [engagement
ring](/wiki/Engagement_ring "Engagement ring") is worn following the practice
of the Romans who "...wore the ring either on the right middle finger or the
left ring [4th] finger, from which, according to ancient Egyptian physicians,
a nerve led directly to the heart."[14] The custom in [Continental
Europe](/wiki/Continental_Europe "Continental Europe") and other countries is
to wear it on the right hand. One historical exception arose in monarchical
regimes, in which a nobleman entering into [morganatic
marriage](/wiki/Morganatic_marriage "Morganatic marriage"), a marriage in
which the person, usually the woman, of lower rank stayed at the same rank
instead of rising ranks, would present their left hand to receive the ring,
hence the alternative term 'marriage with the left hand' (Ger. _Ehe zur linken
Hand_), the offspring of such marriages considered to be disinherited from
birth.[15]

The modern Western form of the practice of giving or exchanging [engagement
rings](/wiki/Engagement_ring "Engagement ring") is traditionally thought to
have begun in 1477 when [Maximilian I, Holy Roman
Emperor](/wiki/Maximilian_I,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Maximilian I, Holy Roman
Emperor"), gave [Mary of Burgundy](/wiki/Mary_of_Burgundy "Mary of Burgundy")
a [diamond](/wiki/Diamond "Diamond") ring as an engagement present.[16]

In other countries like [Argentina](/wiki/Argentina "Argentina"), men and
women each wear a ring similar to wedding bands. They are made of silver
("alianza de plata") when manifesting an informal "boyfriend-girlfriend"
relationship, though this first step might not always happen; howbeit
depending on finances, this may be the only ring given at all. The gold band
("anillo de compromiso" or "alianza de oro") is given to the bride when the
commitment is formal and the [optional] diamond ring ("cintillo") is reserved
for the wedding ceremony when the groom gives it to the bride. The gold band
that the groom wore during the engagement – or a new one, as some men choose
not to wear them during engagement – is then given to the groom by the bride;
and the bride receives both the original gold band and the new diamond at the
ceremony. The bride's diamond ring is worn on top of the engagement band at
the wedding and thereafter, especially at formal occasions or parties;
otherwise the engagement band suffices for daily wear for both parties. At the
wedding, the rings are swapped from the right to the left hand. In
[Brazil](/wiki/Brazil "Brazil"), they are always made of gold, and there is no
tradition for the engagement ring. Both men and women wear the wedding band on
their right hand while engaged, and, after they marry, they shift the rings to
their left hands. In [Nordic countries](/wiki/Nordic_countries "Nordic
countries") such as [Finland](/wiki/Finland "Finland") and
[Norway](/wiki/Norway "Norway"), both men and women wear an engagement ring.

In the modern era, some women's wedding rings are made into two separate
pieces. One part is given to her to wear as an engagement ring when she
accepts the marriage proposal and the other during the wedding ceremony. When
worn together, the two rings look like one piece of jewelry.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The
engagement ring is not worn during the wedding ceremony, when the [wedding
ring](/wiki/Wedding_ring "Wedding ring") is put by the groom on the finger of
the bride, and sometimes by the bride onto the groom's finger. After the
wedding, the engagement ring is put back on, and is usually worn on the
outside of the wedding ring.

## Engagement
parties[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Engagement&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Engagement parties")]

Main article: [Engagement party](/wiki/Engagement_party "Engagement party")

Some engagements are announced at an engagement party, traditionally hosted by
the bride's parents. These parties are given in the family's usual style of
entertainment. Traditionally, engagement parties were normal parties at which
a surprise announcement of the engagement was made by the father of the bride
to his guests. Therefore, it is not a traditional gift-giving occasion since
no guests were supposed to be aware of the engagement until after their
arrival.

In modern times, engagement parties often celebrate a previously publicized
engagement. Whether presents are given at these engagement parties varies from
culture to culture.
